intro: Bryonia dioica var. digyna, commonly known as the greater celandine, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the family Papaveraceae and is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers and fleshy, ribbed stems. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, elliptical seeds. Its leaves are alternate, palmately lobed, and often have a waxy coating. It thrives in disturbed soils and can be found in meadows, roadsides, and other open habitats.
